name: Hops
summary: Hops (Humulus lupulus), widely known for their use in brewing, are also valued in herbal medicine for their sedative, anxiolytic, and sleep-promoting properties.
description: Hops are the flowers of Humulus lupulus, traditionally used in beer brewing and herbal medicine. Rich in bitter acids, essential oils, and flavonoids such as xanthohumol, hops have been studied for their sedative and hypnotic properties. Extracts are commonly used in natural sleep remedies, often in combination with valerian root or passionflower, to reduce anxiety and improve sleep quality. Research suggests that hops modulate GABAergic activity, contributing to calming effects.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for specific medical conditions)

off_label_uses: Menopausal symptom relief (hot flashes, mood swings)
contraindications: Depression (sedative effects may worsen symptoms in some cases)

sections.text: Hops contain bitter acids (humulone, lupulone), essential oils, and prenylflavonoids such as xanthohumol. These compounds exert sedative and anxiolytic effects primarily through modulation of GABA_A receptors, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission. Hops may also influence circadian rhythms and melatonin production, supporting sleep regulation.

adult.typical: 300–500 mg standardized extract at bedtime, or 1–2 g dried hops in tea infusion
adult.note: Often combined with valerian root for synergistic sleep effects.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; insufficient safety data.

sections.text: Sedative effects may be noticed within 30–60 minutes of ingestion; regular use may improve overall sleep quality within days to weeks.

other: May cause excessive sedation when combined with alcohol or CNS depressants.
Caution in individuals with depression or psychiatric conditions due to sedative effects.

items: Assess for excessive drowsiness or next-day sedation
Monitor mood in individuals with depression

sections.lactation: Avoid due to lack of safety data
sections.geriatrics: Caution with sedation; start at lower doses

sections.text: No taper required; can discontinue abruptly without withdrawal.

items: Commonly included in combination herbal sleep formulas with valerian, passionflower, or lemon balm.
Mild to moderate efficacy in improving sleep quality; more effective when used consistently.
Limited clinical trial data compared to other herbal sedatives.

items.label: Franco L, et al. Sleep-inducing effect of hops: A double-blind, placebo-controlled study. Phytother Res. 2012

seo.title: Hops – Herbal Sleep Aid and Natural Sedative
seo.description: Hops (Humulus lupulus) are used as a natural supplement for sleep support, anxiety reduction, and stress relief, often in combination with valerian.
